  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5cd9cd9128b74f7a93e4ba4aac6a164cc6b4d32'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X5cd9cd9128b74f7a93e4ba4aac6a164cc6b4d32'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that administrative users can initiate the password reset
  process for the user, but that this does not allow them to change or choose
  the user’s password. This prevents a situation where they know the user’s
  password.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5cd9cd9128b74f7a93e4ba4aac6a164cc6b4d32'></span></span>

  </td>

<span style='mso-bookmark:X5cd9cd9128b74f7a93e4ba4aac6a164cc6b4d32'></span>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><a
name=Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c></a><a name="_Toc202716435"><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span lang=EN-AU>V6.5
General Multi-factor authentication requirements</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span lang=EN-AU>This
section provides general guidance that will be relevant to various different
multi-factor authentication methods.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span lang=EN-AU>The
mechanisms include:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo50'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Lookup Secrets</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo50'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Time based One-time Passwords
(TOTPs)</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo50'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Out-of-Band mechanisms</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span lang=EN-AU>Lookup
secrets are pre-generated lists of secret codes, similar to Transaction
Authorization Numbers (TAN), social media recovery codes, or a grid containing
a set of random values. This type of authentication mechanism is considered
“something you have” because the codes are deliberately not memorable so will
need to be stored somewhere.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span lang=EN-AU>Time
based One-time Passwords (TOTPs) are physical or soft tokens that display a
continually changing pseudo-random one-time challenge. This type of
authentication mechanism is considered “something you have”. Multi-factor TOTPs
are similar to single-factor TOTPs, but require a valid PIN code, biometric
unlocking, USB insertion or NFC pairing, or some additional value (such as
transaction signing calculators) to be entered to create the final One-time
Password (OTP).</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span lang=EN-AU>Details
on out-of-band mechanisms will be provided in the next section.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span lang=EN-AU>The
requirements in these sections mostly relate to </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#-512-look-up-secrets"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.1.2</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>, </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#-513-out-of-band-devices"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.1.3</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>, </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#5142-single-factor-otp-verifiers"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.1.4.2</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>, </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#5152-multi-factor-otp-verifiers"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.1.5.2</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>, </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#521-physical-authenticators"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.2.1</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>, and </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#523-use-of-biometrics"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.2.3</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU> of </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html"><span style='mso-bookmark:
v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>NIST’s Guidance</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
lang=EN-AU>.</span></span></span></p>

  lang=EN-AU>Verify that lookup secrets, out-of-band authentication requests or
  codes, and time-based one-time passwords (TOTPs) are only successfully usable
  once.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>

 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>6.5.2</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that, when being stored in the application’s backend,
  lookup secrets with less than 112 bits of entropy (19 random alphanumeric
  characters or 34 random digits) are hashed with an approved password storage
  hashing algorithm that incorporates a 32-bit random salt. A standard hash
  function can be used if the secret has 112 bits of entropy or more.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>

  lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:3'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>

  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that lookup secrets, out-of-band authentication code, and
  time-based one-time password seeds, are generated using a Cryptographically
  Secure Pseudorandom Number Generator (CSPRNG) to avoid predictable values.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>

  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:4'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span

  style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that lookup secrets and out-of-band authentication codes
  have a minimum of 20 bits of entropy (typically 4 random alphanumeric
  characters or 6 random digits is sufficient).</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>

  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>

  style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that out-of-band authentication requests, codes, or tokens,
  as well as time-based one-time passwords (TOTPs) have a defined lifetime. Out
  of band requests must have a maximum lifetime of 10 minutes and for TOTP a
  maximum lifetime of 30 seconds.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span></span>

  style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that any authentication factor (including physical devices)

  </td>

  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span

  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'><span

  </td>

  lang=EN-AU>Verify that time-based one-time passwords (TOTPs) are checked
  based on a time source from a trusted service and not from an untrusted or

<span style='mso-bookmark:Xadd92e72de2bf2e3e9d71c4cf90ebddbe83920c'></span>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><a
name=X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2></a><a name="_Toc202716436"><span
style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span lang=EN-AU>V6.6
Out-of-Band authentication mechanisms</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:
X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span lang=EN-AU>This
usually involves the authentication server communicating with a physical device
over a secure secondary channel. For example, sending push notifications to
mobile devices. This type of authentication mechanism is considered “something
you have”.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span lang=EN-AU>Unsafe
out-of-band authentication mechanisms such as e-mail and VOIP are not
permitted. PSTN and SMS authentication are currently considered to be </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-FAQ/#q-b01"><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span lang=EN-AU>“restricted”
authentication mechanisms</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
lang=EN-AU> by NIST and should be deprecated in favor of Time based One-time
Passwords (TOTPs), a cryptographic mechanism, or similar. NIST SP 800-63B </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#-5133-authentication-using-the-public-switched-telephone-network"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.1.3.3</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
lang=EN-AU> recommends addressing the risks of device swap, SIM change, number
porting, or other abnormal behavior, if telephone or SMS out-of-band
authentication absolutely has to be supported. While this ASVS section does not
mandate this as a requirement, not taking these precautions for a sensitive L2
app or an L3 app should be seen as a significant red flag.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span lang=EN-AU>Note
that NIST has also recently provided guidance which </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-4/sp800-63b/authenticators/#fig-3"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
lang=EN-AU>discourages the use of push notifications</span></span></span><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
lang=EN-AU>. While this ASVS section does not do so, it is important to be
aware of the risks of “push bombing”.</span></span></span></p>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;mso-yfti-tbllook:32;mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>

  <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>

   lang=EN-AU>#</span></span></span></p>
   </td>
   <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>

   <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
   style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
   lang=EN-AU>Description</span></span></span></p>
   </td>
   <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
   <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
   <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
   style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
   lang=EN-AU>Level</span></span></span></p>
   </td>
   <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
  </tr>
 </thead>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>6.6.1</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that authentication mechanisms using the Public Switched
  Telephone Network (PSTN) to deliver One-time Passwords (OTPs) via phone or
  SMS are offered only when the phone number has previously been validated,
  alternate stronger methods (such as Time based One-time Passwords) are also
  offered, and the service provides information on their security risks to
  users. For L3 applications, phone and SMS must not be available as options.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>

  lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>6.6.2</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that out-of-band authentication requests, codes, or tokens
  are bound to the original authentication request for which they were
  generated and are not usable for a previous or subsequent one.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span

  lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:3'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>6.6.3</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that a code based out-of-band authentication mechanism is
  protected against brute force attacks by using rate limiting. Consider also
  using a code with at least 64 bits of entropy.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>

  lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>
 </tr>

  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that, where push notifications are used for multi-factor
  authentication, rate limiting is used to prevent push bombing attacks. Number
  matching may also mitigate this risk.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X5b7e4c8ee5e6b772ee480acf1e38b9cd62c10a2'></span></span>

  </td>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><a
name=Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a></a><a name="_Toc202716437"><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'><span lang=EN-AU>V6.7
Cryptographic authentication mechanism</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:
Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'><span lang=EN-AU>Cryptographic
authentication mechanisms include smart cards or FIDO keys, where the user has
to plug in or pair the cryptographic device to the computer to complete
authentication. The authentication server will send a challenge nonce to the
cryptographic device or software, and the device or software calculates a
response based upon a securely stored cryptographic key. The requirements in
this section provide implementation-specific guidance for these mechanisms,
with guidance on cryptographic algorithms being covered in the “Cryptography”
chapter.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'><span lang=EN-AU>Where
shared or secret keys are used for cryptographic authentication, these should
be stored using the same mechanisms as other system secrets, as documented in
the “Secret Management” section in the “Configuration” chapter.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'><span lang=EN-AU>The
requirements in this section mostly relate to </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html#sfcdv"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'><span
lang=EN-AU>§ 5.1.7.2</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'><span
lang=EN-AU> of </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html"><span style='mso-bookmark:
v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:Xb5af0bdc464032c63706b7e29c756b334c4a32a'><span
lang=EN-AU>NIST’s Guidance</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span

lang=EN-AU>.</span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><a
name=X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3></a><a name="_Toc202716438"><span
style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span lang=EN-AU>V6.8
Authentication with an Identity Provider</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span lang=EN-AU>Identity
Providers (IdPs) provide federated identity for users. Users will often have
more than one identity with multiple IdPs, such as an enterprise identity using
Azure AD, Okta, Ping Identity, or Google, or consumer identity using Facebook,
Twitter, Google, or WeChat, to name just a few common alternatives. This list
is not an endorsement of these companies or services, but simply an
encouragement for developers to consider the reality that many users have many
established identities. Organizations should consider integrating with existing
user identities, as per the risk profile of the IdP’s strength of identity
proofing. For example, it is unlikely a government organization would accept a
social media identity as a login for sensitive systems, as it is easy to create
fake or throwaway identities, whereas a mobile game company may well need to
integrate with major social media platforms to grow their active player base.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span lang=EN-AU>Secure
use of external identity providers requires careful configuration and
verification to prevent identity spoofing or forged assertions. This section
provides requirements to address these risks.</span></span></span></p>

 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>6.8.1</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that, if the application supports multiple identity
  providers (IdPs), the user’s identity cannot be spoofed via another supported
  identity provider (eg. by using the same user identifier). The standard
  mitigation would be for the application to register and identify the user
  using a combination of the IdP ID (serving as a namespace) and the user’s ID

 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span

  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'></span></span>

  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that the presence and integrity of digital signatures on
  authentication assertions (for example on JWTs or SAML assertions) are always
  validated, rejecting any assertions that are unsigned or have invalid

  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span
  lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>

  style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that SAML assertions are uniquely processed and used only
  once within the validity period to prevent replay attacks.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'></span></span>

  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span

  lang=EN-AU>6.8.4</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that, if an application uses a separate Identity Provider
  (IdP) and expects specific authentication strength, methods, or recentness
  for specific functions, the application verifies this using the information
  returned by the IdP. For example, if OIDC is used, this might be achieved by
  validating ID Token claims such as ‘acr’, ‘amr’, and ‘auth_time’ (if
  present). If the IdP does not provide this information, the application must
  have a documented fallback approach that assumes that the minimum strength
  authentication mechanism was used (for example, single-factor authentication
  using username and password).</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v6-authentication'><span style='mso-bookmark:X71c038296e24629c9e5e3512f785c16a8ef6bd3'></span></span>

  lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>

<h1><a name=v7-session-management></a><a name="_Toc202716440"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span lang=EN-AU>V7 Session
Management</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'></span></h1>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><a
name=control-objective-6></a><a name="_Toc202716441"><span style='mso-bookmark:
control-objective-6'><span lang=EN-AU>Control Objective</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><span lang=EN-AU>Session management
mechanisms allow applications to correlate user and device interactions over
time, even when using stateless communication protocols (such as HTTP). Modern
applications may use multiple session tokens with distinct characteristics and purposes.
A secure session management system is one that prevents attackers from
obtaining, utilizing, or otherwise abusing a victim’s session. Applications
maintaining sessions must ensure that the following high-level session
management requirements are met:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo52'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Sessions are unique to each
individual and cannot be guessed or shared.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo52'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Sessions are invalidated when
no longer required and are timed out during periods of inactivity.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><span lang=EN-AU>Many of the
requirements in this chapter relate to selected </span></span></span><a
href="https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-4/"><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><span lang=EN-AU>NIST SP 800-63
Digital Identity Guidelines</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><span
lang=EN-AU> controls, focusing on common threats and commonly exploited
authentication weaknesses.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><span lang=EN-AU>Note that
requirements for specific implementation details of certain session management
mechanisms can be found elsewhere:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo53'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>HTTP Cookies are a common
mechanism for securing session tokens. Specific security requirements for
cookies can be found in the “Web Frontend Security” chapter.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo53'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Self-contained tokens are
frequently used as a way of maintaining sessions. Specific security
requirements can be found in the “Self-contained Tokens” chapter.</span></span></span></p>

<span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-6'></span>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><a
name=v7.1-session-management-documentation></a><a name="_Toc202716442"><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.1-session-management-documentation"'><span lang=EN-AU>V7.1
Session Management Documentation</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:
"v7\.1-session-management-documentation"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.1-session-management-documentation"'><span lang=EN-AU>There
is no single pattern that suits all applications. Therefore, it is not feasible
to define universal boundaries and limits that suit all cases. A risk analysis
with documented security decisions related to session handling must be
conducted as a prerequisite to implementation and testing. This ensures that
the session management system is tailored to the specific requirements of the
application.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.1-session-management-documentation"'><span lang=EN-AU>Regardless
of whether a stateful or “stateless” session mechanism is chosen, the analysis
must be complete and documented to demonstrate that the selected solution is
capable of satisfying all relevant security requirements. Interaction with any
Single Sign-on (SSO) mechanisms in use should also be considered.</span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><a
name=v7.4-session-termination></a><a name="_Toc202716445"><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.4-session-termination"'><span lang=EN-AU>V7.4 Session
Termination</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.4-session-termination"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.4-session-termination"'><span lang=EN-AU>Session
termination may be handled either by the application itself or by the SSO
provider if the SSO provider is handling session management instead of the
application. It may be necessary to decide whether the SSO provider is in scope
when considering the requirements in this section as some may be controlled by
the provider.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.4-session-termination"'><span lang=EN-AU>Session
termination should result in requiring re-authentication and be effective
across the application, federated login (if present), and any relying parties.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v7-session-management'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v7\.4-session-termination"'><span lang=EN-AU>For stateful
session mechanisms, termination typically involves invalidating the session on
the backend. In the case of self-contained tokens, additional measures are
required to revoke or block these tokens, as they may otherwise remain valid
until expiration.</span></span></span></p>

  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span

  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify
  that the application enforces authorization rules at a trusted service layer
  and doesn’t rely on controls that an untrusted consumer could manipulate,
  such as client-side JavaScript.</span></span></span></p>

  <span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><span
  lang=EN-AU>1</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>8.3.2</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify
  that changes to values on which authorization decisions are made are applied
  immediately. Where changes cannot be applied immediately, (such as when
  relying on data in self-contained tokens), there must be mitigating controls
  to alert when a consumer performs an action when they are no longer
  authorized to do so and revert the change. Note that this alternative would
  not mitigate information leakage.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><span
  lang=EN-AU>3</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:3;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>8.3.3</span></b></span></span></p>

  <span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify
  that access to an object is based on the originating subject’s
  (e.g.&nbsp;consumer’s) permissions, not on the permissions of any
  intermediary or service acting on their behalf. For example, if a consumer
  calls a web service using a self-contained token for authentication, and the
  service then requests data from a different service, the second service will
  use the consumer’s token, rather than a machine-to-machine token from the
  first service, to make permission decisions.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>

  style='mso-bookmark:v8-authorization'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v8\.3-operation-level-authorization"'><span
  lang=EN-AU>3</span></span></span></p>
  </td>

 </tr>

<h1><a name=v9-self-contained-tokens></a><a name="_Toc202716456"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span lang=EN-AU>V9
Self-contained Tokens</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'></span></h1>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><a
name=control-objective-8></a><a name="_Toc202716457"><span style='mso-bookmark:
control-objective-8'><span lang=EN-AU>Control Objective</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-8'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-8'><span lang=EN-AU>The concept of a
self-contained token is mentioned in the original RFC 6749 OAuth 2.0 from 2012.
It refers to a token containing data or claims on which a receiving service
will rely to make security decisions. This should be differentiated from a
simple token containing only an identifier, which a receiving service uses to
look up data locally. The most common examples of self-contained tokens are
JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) and SAML assertions.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-8'><span lang=EN-AU>The use of
self-contained tokens has become very widespread, even outside of OAuth and
OIDC. At the same time, the security of this mechanism relies on the ability to
validate the integrity of the token and to ensure that the token is valid for a
particular context. There are many pitfalls with this process, and this chapter
provides specific details of the mechanisms that applications should have in
place to prevent them.</span></span></span></p>

<span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-8'></span>

name=v9.1-token-source-and-integrity></a><a name="_Toc202716458"><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.1-token-source-and-integrity"'><span lang=EN-AU>V9.1

  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.1-token-source-and-integrity"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify
  that only algorithms on an allowlist can be used to create and verify
  self-contained tokens, for a given context. The allowlist must include the
  permitted algorithms, ideally only either symmetric or asymmetric algorithms,
  and must not include the ‘None’ algorithm. If both symmetric and asymmetric
  must be supported, additional controls will be needed to prevent key
  confusion.</span></span></span></p>

  style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.1-token-source-and-integrity"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify
  that key material that is used to validate self-contained tokens is from
  trusted pre-configured sources for the token issuer, preventing attackers
  from specifying untrusted sources and keys. For JWTs and other JWS

 </tr>
</table>

<span style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.1-token-source-and-integrity"'></span>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><a
name=v9.2-token-content></a><a name="_Toc202716459"><span style='mso-bookmark:
"v9\.2-token-content"'><span lang=EN-AU>V9.2 Token content</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span lang=EN-AU>Before making
security decisions based on the content of a self-contained token, it is
necessary to validate that the token has been presented within its validity
period and that it is intended for use by the receiving service and for the
purpose for which it was presented. This helps avoid insecure cross-usage
between different services or with different token types from the same issuer.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span lang=EN-AU>Specific
requirements for OAuth and OIDC are covered in the dedicated chapter.</span></span></span></p>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;mso-yfti-tbllook:32;mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
 <thead>
  <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>
   <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
   <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
   style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:

 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>9.2.1</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that, if a
  validity time span is present in the token data, the token and its content
  are accepted only if the verification time is within this validity time span.
  For example, for JWTs, the claims ‘nbf’ and ‘exp’ must be verified.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:

  style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span
  lang=EN-AU>1</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>9.2.2</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that the
  service receiving a token validates the token to be the correct type and is
  meant for the intended purpose before accepting the token’s contents. For
  example, only access tokens can be accepted for authorization decisions and
  only ID Tokens can be used for proving user authentication.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>

  style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span
  lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:3'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>9.2.3</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that the
  service only accepts tokens which are intended for use with that service
  (audience). For JWTs, this can be achieved by validating the ‘aud’ claim
  against an allowlist defined in the service.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:

  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:4;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>9.2.4</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span style='mso-bookmark:
  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v9-self-contained-tokens'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v9\.2-token-content"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that, if a
  token issuer uses the same private key for issuing tokens to different
  audiences, the issued tokens contain an audience restriction that uniquely
  identifies the intended audiences. This will prevent a token from being
  reused with an unintended audience. If the audience identifier is dynamically
  provisioned, the token issuer must validate these audiences in order to make
  sure that they do not result in audience impersonation.</span></span></span></p>

  "v9\.2-token-content"'></span></span>
 </tr>

<h1><a name=v10-oauth-and-oidc></a><a name="_Toc202716461"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span lang=EN-AU>V10 OAuth and OIDC</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'></span></h1>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><a name=control-objective-9></a><a
name="_Toc202716462"><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span
lang=EN-AU>Control Objective</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>OAuth2 (referred to
as OAuth in this chapter) is an industry-standard framework for delegated
authorization. For example, using OAuth, a client application can obtain access
to APIs (server resources) on a user’s behalf, provided the user has authorized
the client application to do so.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>By itself, OAuth is
not designed for user authentication. The OpenID Connect (OIDC) framework
extends OAuth by adding a user identity layer on top of OAuth. OIDC provides
support for features including standardized user information, Single Sign-On
(SSO), and session management. As OIDC is an extension of OAuth, the OAuth
requirements in this chapter also apply to OIDC.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>The following roles
are defined in OAuth:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo58'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>The OAuth client is the
application that attempts to obtain access to server resources (e.g., by
calling an API using the issued access token). The OAuth client is often a
server-side application.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level2 lfo59'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>–<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>A confidential client is a
client capable of maintaining the confidentiality of the credentials it uses to
authenticate itself with the authorization server.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level2 lfo59'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>–<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>A public client is not capable
of maintaining the confidentiality of credentials for authenticating with the
authorization server. Therefore, instead of authenticating itself (e.g., using
‘client_id’ and ‘client_secret’ parameters), it only identifies itself (using a
‘client_id’ parameter).</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo58'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>The OAuth resource server (RS)
is the server API exposing resources to OAuth clients.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo58'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>The OAuth authorization server
(AS) is a server application that issues access tokens to OAuth clients. These
access tokens allow OAuth clients to access RS resources, either on behalf of
an end-user or on the OAuth client’s own behalf. The AS is often a separate
application, but (if appropriate) it may be integrated into a suitable RS.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo58'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>The resource owner (RO) is the
end-user who authorizes OAuth clients to obtain limited access to resources
hosted on the resource server on their behalf. The resource owner consents to
this delegated authorization by interacting with the authorization server.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>The following roles
are defined in OIDC:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo60'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>The relying party (RP) is the
client application requesting end-user authentication through the OpenID
Provider. It assumes the role of an OAuth client.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo60'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>The OpenID Provider (OP) is an
OAuth AS that is capable of authenticating the end-user and provides OIDC
claims to an RP. The OP may be the identity provider (IdP), but in federated
scenarios, the OP and the identity provider (where the end-user authenticates)
may be different server applications.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>OAuth and OIDC were
initially designed for third-party applications. Today, they are often used by
first-party applications as well. However, when used in first-party scenarios,
such as authentication and session management, the protocol adds some complexity,
which may introduce new security challenges.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>OAuth and OIDC can be
used for many types of applications, but the focus for ASVS and the
requirements in this chapter is on web applications and APIs.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>Since OAuth and OIDC
can be considered logic on top of web technologies, general requirements from
other chapters always apply, and this chapter cannot be taken out of context.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>This chapter
addresses best current practices for OAuth2 and OIDC aligned with
specifications found at </span></span></span><a href="https://oauth.net/2/"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span
lang=EN-AU>https://oauth.net/2/</span></span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:
v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span
lang=EN-AU> and </span></span></span><a
href="https://openid.net/developers/specs/"><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>https://openid.net/developers/specs/</span></span></span><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span
lang=EN-AU>. Even if RFCs are considered mature, they are updated frequently.
Thus, it is important to align with the latest versions when applying the
requirements in this chapter. See the references section for more details.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>Given the complexity
of the area, it is vitally important for a secure OAuth or OIDC solution to use
well-known industry-standard authorization servers and apply the recommended
security configuration.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>Terminology used in
this chapter aligns with OAuth RFCs and OIDC specifications, but note that OIDC
terminology is only used for OIDC-specific requirements; otherwise, OAuth
terminology is used.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>In the context of
OAuth and OIDC, the term “token” in this chapter refers to:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo61'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Access tokens, which shall only
be consumed by the RS and can either be reference tokens that are validated
using introspection or self-contained tokens that are validated using some key
material.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo61'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Refresh tokens, which shall
only be consumed by the authorization server that issued the token.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo61'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>OIDC ID Tokens, which shall
only be consumed by the client that triggered the authorization flow.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'><span lang=EN-AU>The risk levels for
some of the requirements in this chapter depend on whether the client is a
confidential client or regarded as a public client. Since using strong client
authentication mitigates many attack vectors, a few requirements might be
relaxed when using a confidential client for L1 applications.</span></span></span></p>

<span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-9'></span>

  lang=EN-AU>Verify that the client only accepts values from the authorization
  server (such as the authorization code or ID Token) if these values result
  from an authorization flow that was initiated by the same user agent session

  both the client and the user agent session in which the transaction was
  started.</span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><a name=v10.2-oauth-client></a><a
name="_Toc202716464"><span style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.2-oauth-client"'><span
lang=EN-AU>V10.2 OAuth Client</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.2-oauth-client"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.2-oauth-client"'><span lang=EN-AU>These requirements
detail the responsibilities for OAuth client applications. The client can be,
for example, a web server backend (often acting as a Backend For Frontend,
BFF), a backend service integration, or a frontend Single Page Application
(SPA, aka browser-based application).</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.2-oauth-client"'><span lang=EN-AU>In general, backend
clients are regarded as confidential clients and frontend clients are regarded
as public clients. However, native applications running on the end-user device
can be regarded as confidential when using OAuth dynamic client registration.</span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><a
name=v10.3-oauth-resource-server></a><a name="_Toc202716465"><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'><span lang=EN-AU>V10.3
OAuth Resource Server</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'><span lang=EN-AU>In the
context of ASVS and this chapter, the resource server is an API. To provide
secure access, the resource server must:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo62'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Validate the access token,
according to the token format and relevant protocol specifications, e.g.,
JWT-validation or OAuth token introspection.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo62'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>If valid, enforce authorization
decisions based on the information from the access token and permissions which
have been granted. For example, the resource server needs to verify that the
client (acting on behalf of RO) is authorized to access the requested resource.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'><span lang=EN-AU>Therefore,
the requirements listed here are OAuth or OIDC specific and should be performed
after token validation and before performing authorization based on information
from the token.</span></span></span></p>

  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'><b><span

  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v10-oauth-and-oidc'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v10\.3-oauth-resource-server"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify
  that the resource server only accepts access tokens that are intended for use
  with that service (audience). The audience may be included in a structured
