  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span

  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that third-party components and all of their transitive
  dependencies are included from the expected repository, whether internally
  owned or an external source, and that there is no risk of a dependency
  confusion attack.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'><span
  lang=EN-AU>3</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'></span></span>
 </tr>

  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>

  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>15.2.5</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'><span
  lang=EN-AU>Verify that the application implements additional protections
  around parts of the application which are documented as containing “dangerous
  functionality” or using third-party libraries considered to be “risky
  components”. This could include techniques such as sandboxing, encapsulation,
  containerization or network level isolation to delay and deter attackers who
  compromise one part of an application from pivoting elsewhere in the
  application.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'></span></span>

  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'><span
  lang=EN-AU>3</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'></span></span>

<span style='mso-bookmark:Xb57b3c253c4041fc8c2d6c1614d044721eaa4b8'></span>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><a
name=v15.3-defensive-coding></a><a name="_Toc202716504"><span style='mso-bookmark:
"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>V15.3 Defensive Coding</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>This section
covers vulnerability types, including type juggling, prototype pollution, and
others, which result from using insecure coding patterns in a particular
language. Some may not be relevant to all languages, whereas others will have
language-specific fixes or may relate to how a particular language or framework
handles a feature such as HTTP parameters. It also considers the risk of not
cryptographically validating application updates.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>It also
considers the risks associated with using objects to represent data items and
accepting and returning these via external APIs. In this case, the application
must ensure that data fields that should not be writable are not modified by
user input (mass assignment) and that the API is selective about what data
fields get returned. Where field access depends on a user’s permissions, this
should be considered in the context of the field-level access control
requirement in the Authorization chapter.</span></span></span></p>

 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><b><span lang=EN-AU>15.3.1</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  the application only returns the required subset of fields from a data
  object. For example, it should not return an entire data object, as some
  individual fields should not be accessible to users.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>1</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><b><span lang=EN-AU>15.3.2</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  where the application backend makes calls to external URLs, it is configured
  to not follow redirects unless it is intended functionality.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:3'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><b><span lang=EN-AU>15.3.3</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  the application has countermeasures to protect against mass assignment
  attacks by limiting allowed fields per controller and action, e.g., it is not
  possible to insert or update a field value when it was not intended to be
  part of that action.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:4'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><b><span lang=EN-AU>15.3.4</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  all proxying and middleware components transfer the user’s original IP
  address correctly using trusted data fields that cannot be manipulated by the
  end user, and the application and web server use this correct value for
  logging and security decisions such as rate limiting, taking into account
  that even the original IP address may not be reliable due to dynamic IPs,
  VPNs, or corporate firewalls.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:5'>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><b><span lang=EN-AU>15.3.5</span></b></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  the application explicitly ensures that variables are of the correct type and
  performs strict equality and comparator operations. This is to avoid type
  juggling or type confusion vulnerabilities caused by the application code
  making an assumption about a variable type.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.3-defensive-coding"'><span lang=EN-AU>2</span></span></span></p>
  </td>
  <span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><a
name=v15.4-safe-concurrency></a><a name="_Toc202716505"><span style='mso-bookmark:
"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'><span lang=EN-AU>V15.4 Safe Concurrency</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'><span lang=EN-AU>Concurrency
issues such as race conditions, time-of-check to time-of-use (TOCTOU)
vulnerabilities, deadlocks, livelocks, thread starvation, and improper
synchronization can lead to unpredictable behavior and security risks. This
section includes various techniques and strategies to help mitigate these
risks.</span></span></span></p>

  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  shared objects in multi-threaded code (such as caches, files, or in-memory
  objects accessed by multiple threads) are accessed safely by using
  thread-safe types and synchronization mechanisms like locks or semaphores to
  avoid race conditions and data corruption.</span></span></span></p>

  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'></span></span>
 </tr>

  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span

  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'><b><span lang=EN-AU>15.4.2</span></b></span></span></p>

  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'></span></span>
  <td valign=top style='padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v15-secure-coding-and-architecture'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  checks on a resource’s state, such as its existence or permissions, and the
  actions that depend on them are performed as a single atomic operation to
  prevent time-of-check to time-of-use (TOCTOU) race conditions. For example,
  checking if a file exists before opening it, or verifying a user’s access
  before granting it.</span></span></span></p>
  </td>

  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'></span></span>

  style='mso-bookmark:"v15\.4-safe-concurrency"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that
  locks are used consistently to avoid threads getting stuck, whether by
  waiting on each other or retrying endlessly, and that locking logic stays
  within the code responsible for managing the resource to ensure locks cannot
  be inadvertently or maliciously modified by external classes or code.</span></span></span></p>

<h1><a name=v16-security-logging-and-error-handling></a><a name="_Toc202716507"><span
style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span lang=EN-AU>V16
Security Logging and Error Handling</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:
v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'></span></h1>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><a
name=control-objective-15></a><a name="_Toc202716508"><span style='mso-bookmark:
control-objective-15'><span lang=EN-AU>Control Objective</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-15'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-15'><span lang=EN-AU>Security logs are
distinct from error or performance logs and are used to record
security-relevant events such as authentication decisions, access control
decisions, and attempts to bypass security controls, such as input validation
or business logic validation. Their purpose is to support detection, response,
and investigation by providing high-signal, structured data for analysis tools
like SIEMs.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-15'><span lang=EN-AU>Logs should not
include sensitive personal data unless legally required, and any logged data
must be protected as a high-value asset. Logging must not compromise privacy or
system security. Applications must also fail securely, avoiding unnecessary
disclosure or disruption.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-15'><span lang=EN-AU>For detailed
implementation guidance, refer to the OWASP Cheat Sheets in the references
section.</span></span></span></p>

<span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-15'></span>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><a
name=v16.2-general-logging></a><a name="_Toc202716510"><span style='mso-bookmark:
"v16\.2-general-logging"'><span lang=EN-AU>V16.2 General Logging</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.2-general-logging"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.2-general-logging"'><span lang=EN-AU>This section
provides requirements to ensure that security logs are consistently structured
and contain the expected metadata. The goal is to make logs machine-readable
and analyzable across distributed systems and tools.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.2-general-logging"'><span lang=EN-AU>Naturally,
security events often involve sensitive data. If such data is logged without
consideration, the logs themselves become classified and therefore subject to
encryption requirements, stricter retention policies, and potential disclosure
during audits.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.2-general-logging"'><span lang=EN-AU>Therefore, it is
critical to log only what is necessary and to treat log data with the same care
as other sensitive assets.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.2-general-logging"'><span lang=EN-AU>The requirements
below establish foundational requirements for logging metadata,
synchronization, format, and control.</span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><a

"v16\.3-security-events"'><span lang=EN-AU>V16.3 Security Events</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.3-security-events"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.3-security-events"'><span lang=EN-AU>This section
defines requirements for logging security-relevant events within the
application. Capturing these events is critical for detecting suspicious
behavior, supporting investigations, and fulfilling compliance obligations.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.3-security-events"'><span lang=EN-AU>This section
outlines the types of events that should be logged but does not attempt to
provide exhaustive detail. Each application has unique risk factors and
operational context.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.3-security-events"'><span lang=EN-AU>Note that while
ASVS includes logging of security events in scope, alerting and correlation
(e.g., SIEM rules or monitoring infrastructure) are considered out of scope and
are handled by operational and monitoring systems.</span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><a
name=v16.4-log-protection></a><a name="_Toc202716512"><span style='mso-bookmark:
"v16\.4-log-protection"'><span lang=EN-AU>V16.4 Log Protection</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.4-log-protection"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v16-security-logging-and-error-handling'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v16\.4-log-protection"'><span lang=EN-AU>Logs are valuable
forensic artifacts and must be protected. If logs can be easily modified or
deleted, they lose their integrity and become unreliable for incident
investigations or legal proceedings. Logs may expose internal application
behavior or sensitive metadata, making them an attractive target for attackers.</span></span></span></p>

<h1><a name=v17-webrtc></a><a name="_Toc202716515"><span style='mso-bookmark:
v17-webrtc'><span lang=EN-AU>V17 WebRTC</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'></span></h1>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><a name=control-objective-16></a><a
name="_Toc202716516"><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><span
lang=EN-AU>Control Objective</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><span lang=EN-AU>Web Real-Time
Communication (WebRTC) enables real-time voice, video, and data exchange in
modern applications. As adoption increases, securing WebRTC infrastructure
becomes critical. This section provides security requirements for stakeholders
who develop, host, or integrate WebRTC systems.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><span lang=EN-AU>The WebRTC market
can be broadly categorized into three segments:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo74'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>1.<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Product Developers: Proprietary
and open-source vendors that create and supply WebRTC products and solutions.
Their focus is on developing robust and secure WebRTC technologies that can be
used by others.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo74'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>2.<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Communication Platforms as a
Service (CPaaS): Providers that offer APIs, SDKs, and the necessary
infrastructure or platforms to enable WebRTC functionalities. CPaaS providers
may use products from the first category or develop their own WebRTC software to
offer these services.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo74'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>3.<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Service Providers:
Organizations that leverage products from product developers or CPaaS
providers, or develop their own WebRTC solutions. They create and implement
applications for online conferencing, healthcare, e-learning, and other domains
where real-time communication is crucial.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><span lang=EN-AU>The security
requirements outlined here are primarily focused on Product Developers, CPaaS,
and Service Providers who:</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo75'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Utilize open-source solutions
to build their WebRTC applications.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo75'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Use commercial WebRTC products
as part of their infrastructure.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo75'><span
style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Use internally developed WebRTC
solutions or integrate various components into a cohesive service offering.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'><span lang=EN-AU>It is important to
note that these security requirements do not apply to developers who
exclusively use SDKs and APIs provided by CPaaS vendors. For such developers,
the CPaaS providers are typically responsible for most of the underlying
security concerns within their platforms, and a generic security standard like
ASVS may not fully address their needs.</span></span></span></p>

<span style='mso-bookmark:control-objective-16'></span>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><a name=v17.1-turn-server></a><a
name="_Toc202716517"><span style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.1-turn-server"'><span
lang=EN-AU>V17.1 TURN Server</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.1-turn-server"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.1-turn-server"'><span lang=EN-AU>This section defines
security requirements for systems that operate their own TURN (Traversal Using
Relays around NAT) servers. TURN servers assist in relaying media in
restrictive network environments but can pose risks if misconfigured. These
controls focus on secure address filtering and protection against resource
exhaustion.</span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><a name=v17.2-media></a><a
name="_Toc202716518"><span style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.2-media"'><span
lang=EN-AU>V17.2 Media</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.2-media"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.2-media"'><span lang=EN-AU>These requirements only
apply to systems that host their own WebRTC media servers, such as Selective
Forwarding Units (SFUs), Multipoint Control Units (MCUs), recording servers, or
gateway servers. Media servers handle and distribute media streams, making
their security critical to protect communication between peers. Safeguarding
media streams is paramount in WebRTC applications to prevent eavesdropping,
tampering, and denial-of-service attacks that could compromise user privacy and
communication quality.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.2-media"'><span lang=EN-AU>In particular, it is
necessary to implement protections against flood attacks such as rate limiting,
validating timestamps, using synchronized clocks to match real-time intervals,
and managing buffers to prevent overflow and maintain proper timing. If packets
for a particular media session arrive too quickly, excess packets should be
dropped. It is also important to protect the system from malformed packets by
implementing input validation, safely handling integer overflows, preventing
buffer overflows, and employing other robust error-handling techniques.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.2-media"'><span lang=EN-AU>Systems that rely solely
on peer-to-peer media communication between web browsers, without the
involvement of intermediate media servers, are excluded from these specific
media-related security requirements.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.2-media"'><span lang=EN-AU>This section refers to the
use of Datagram Transport Layer Security (DTLS) in the context of WebRTC. A
requirement related to having a documented policy for the management of
cryptographic keys can be found in the “Cryptography” chapter. Information on approved
cryptographic methods can be found either in the Cryptography Appendix of the
ASVS or in documents such as NIST SP 800‑52 Rev.&nbsp;2 or BSI TR‑02102‑2
(Version 2025‑01).</span></span></span></p>

  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.2-media"'><b><span
  lang=EN-AU>17.2.3</span></b></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><a name=v17.3-signaling></a><a
name="_Toc202716519"><span style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.3-signaling"'><span
lang=EN-AU>V17.3 Signaling</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.3-signaling"'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.3-signaling"'><span lang=EN-AU>This section defines
requirements for systems that operate their own WebRTC signaling servers.
Signaling coordinates peer-to-peer communication and must be resilient against
attacks that could disrupt session establishment or control.</span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.3-signaling"'><span lang=EN-AU>To ensure secure
signaling, systems must handle malformed inputs gracefully and remain available
under load.</span></span></span></p>

  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:v17-webrtc'><span
  style='mso-bookmark:"v17\.3-signaling"'><span lang=EN-AU>Verify that the
  signaling server is able to continue processing legitimate signaling messages
  when encountering malformed signaling message that could cause a denial of
  service condition. This could include implementing input validation, safely
  handling integer overflows, preventing buffer overflows, and employing other
  robust error-handling techniques.</span></span></span></p>
