<h1><a name=appendix-a-glossary></a><a name="_Toc202716521"><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><span lang=EN-AU>Appendix A: Glossary</span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Absolute Maximum Session
Lifetime</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> – Also referred to as “Overall Timeout” by
NIST, this is the maximal amount of time a session can remain active following
authentication regardless of user interaction. This is a component of session
expiration.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Allowlist</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A list of permitted data or operations, for example, a list of
characters that are allowed to perform input validation.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Anti-forgery token</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A mechanism by which one or more tokens are passed in a request
and validated by the application server to ensure that the request has come
from an expected endpoint.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Application Security</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – Application-level security focuses on the analysis of components
that comprise the application layer of the Open Systems Interconnection
Reference Model (OSI Model), rather than focusing on for example the underlying
operating system or connected networks.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Application Security
Verification</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> – The technical assessment of an
application against the OWASP ASVS.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Application Security
Verification Report</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> – A report that documents the
overall results and supporting analysis produced by the verifier for a
particular application.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Authentication</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – The verification of the claimed identity of an application user.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Automated Verification</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – The use of automated tools (either dynamic analysis tools, static
analysis tools, or both) that use vulnerability signatures to find problems.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Black box testing</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A method of software testing that examines the functionality of
an application without peering into its internal structures or workings.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Common Weakness Enumeration</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (CWE) – A community-developed list of common software security
weaknesses. It serves as a common language, a measuring stick for software
security tools, and a baseline for weakness identification, mitigation, and
prevention efforts.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Component</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A self-contained unit of code, with associated disk and network
interfaces that communicates with other components.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Credential Service Provider</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (CSP) – Also called an Identity Provider (IdP). A source of user
data which may be used as an authentication source by other applications.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Cross-Site Script Inclusion</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (XSSI) - A variant of Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attack in which a
web application retrieves malicious code from an external resource and includes
that code as part of its own content.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Cross-Site Scripting</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (XSS) – A security vulnerability typically found in web
applications allowing the injection of client-side scripts into content.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Cryptographic module</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – Hardware, software, and/or firmware that implements cryptographic
algorithms and/or generates cryptographic keys.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Cryptographically secure
pseudo-random number generator</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (CSPRNG) - A
pseudorandom number generator with properties that make it suitable for use in
cryptography, also referred to as a cryptographic random number generator
(CRNG).</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Datagram Transport Layer
Security</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (DTLS) – A cryptographic protocol which
provides communication security over a network connection. It is based on the
TLS protocol but adapted for protecting datagram-oriented protocols (usually
over UDP). Defined in RFC 9147 for DTLS 1.3.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Datagram Transport Layer
Security Extension to Establish Keys for the Secure Real-time Transport
Protocol</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (DTLS-SRTP) – A mechanism for using a DTLS
handshake for establishing key material for a SRTP session. Defined in RFC
5764.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Design Verification</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – The technical assessment of the security architecture of an
application.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Dynamic Application Security
Testing</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (DAST) – Technologies are designed to
detect conditions indicative of a security vulnerability in an application in
its running state.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Dynamic Verification</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – The use of automated tools that use vulnerability signatures to
find problems during the execution of an application.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Fast IDentity Online</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (FIDO) – A set of authentication standards that allow a variety of
different authentication methods to be used including biometrics, Trusted
Platform Modules (TPMs), USB security tokens, etc.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Hardware Security Module</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (HSM) – Hardware component that stores cryptographic keys and other
secrets in a protected manner.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Hibernate Query Language</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (HQL) – A query language that is similar in appearance to SQL used
by the Hibernate ORM library.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>HTTP Strict Transport
Security</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (HSTS) – An policy which instructs the
browser to only connect to the domain returning the header via TLS and when a
valid certificate is presented. It is activated using the
Strict-Transport-Security response header field.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>HyperText Transfer Protocol</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (HTTP) – An application protocol for distributed, collaborative,
hypermedia information systems. It is the foundation of data communication for
the World Wide Web.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>HyperText Transfer Protocol
over SSL/TLS</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (HTTPS) – A method of securing HTTP
communication by encrypting it using Transport Layer Security (TLS).</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Identity Provider</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (IdP) – Also called a Credential Service Provider (CSP) in NIST
references. An entity that provides an authentication source for other
applications.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Inactivity Timeout</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – This is the length of time a session can remain active in the
absence of user interaction with the application. This is a component of
session expiration.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Input Validation</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – The canonicalization and validation of untrusted user input.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>JSON Web Token</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (JWT) – RFC 7519 defines a standard for a JSON data object made up
of a header section which explains how to validate the object, a body section
containing a set of claims, and a signature section which contains a digital
signature which can be used to validate the contents of the body section. It is
a type of self-contained token.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Local File Inclusion</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (LFI) - An attack that exploits vulnerable file inclusion
procedures in an application, leading to the inclusion of local files already
present on the server.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Malicious Code</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – Code introduced into an application during its development
unbeknownst to the application owner, which circumvents the application’s
intended security policy. Not the same as malware such as a virus or worm!</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Malware</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – Executable code that is introduced into an application during
runtime without the knowledge of the application user or administrator.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Message authentication code</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (MAC) - A cryptographic checksum on data, computed by a MAC
generation algorithm, that is used to provide assurance on its integrity and
authenticity.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Multi-factor authentication</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (MFA) – Authentication which includes two or more of the single
factors.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Mutual TLS</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (mTLS) – See TLS client authentication.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Object-relational Mapping</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (ORM) – A system used to allow a relational/table-based database to
be referenced and queried within an application program using an
application-compatible object model.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>One-time Password</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (OTP) – A password that is uniquely generated to be used on a
single occasion.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Open Worldwide Application
Security Project</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (OWASP) – The Open Worldwide
Application Security Project (OWASP) is a worldwide free and open community
focused on improving the security of application software. Our mission is to
make application security “visible,” so that people and organizations can make
informed decisions about application security risks. See: </span></span><a
href="https://www.owasp.org/"><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><span
lang=EN-AU>https://www.owasp.org/</span></span><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><span lang=EN-AU>.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Password-Based Key
Derivation Function 2</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (PBKDF2) – A special one-way
algorithm used to create a strong cryptographic key from an input text (such as
a password) and an additional random salt value and can therefore be used to
make it harder to crack a password offline if the resulting value is stored
instead of the original password.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Public Key Infrastructure</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (PKI) – An arrangement that binds public keys with respective
identities of entities. The binding is established through a process of
registration and issuance of certificates at and by a certificate authority
(CA).</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Public Switched Telephone
Network</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (PSTN) – The traditional telephone network
that includes both fixed-line telephones and mobile telephones.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Real-time Transport Protocol</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (RTP) and <b>Real-time Transport Control Protocol</b> (RTCP) – Two
protocols used in association for transporting multimedia streams. Used by the
WebRTC stack. Defined in RFC 3550.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Reference Token</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A type of token that acts as a pointer or identifier to state or
metadata stored on a server, sometimes referred to as random tokens or opaque
tokens. Unlike self-contained tokens, which embed some of their relevant data
within the token itself, reference tokens contain no intrinsic information,
instead relying on the server for context. The reference token will either be
or contain a session identifier.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Relying Party</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (RP) – Generally an application which is relying on a user having
authenticated against a separate authentication provider. The application
relies on some sort of token or set of signed assertions provided by that
authentication provider to trust that the user is who they say they are.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Remote File Inclusion</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (RFI) - An attack that exploits vulnerable inclusion procedures in
the application, resulting in the inclusion of remote files.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Scalable Vector Graphics</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (SVG) – An XML-based markup language for describing two-dimensional
based vector graphics.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Secure Real-time Transport
Protocol</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (SRTP) and <b>Secure Real-time Transport
Control Protocol</b> (SRTCP) – A profile of the RTP and RTCP protocols
providing support for message encryption, authentication and integrity
protection. Defined in RFC 3711.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Security Architecture</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – An abstraction of an application’s design that identifies and
describes where and how security controls are used, and also identifies and
describes the location and sensitivity of both user and application data.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Security Assertion Markup
Language</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (SAML) – An open standard for single
sign-on authentication based on passing signed assertions (usually XML objects)
between the identity provider and the relying party.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Security Configuration</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – The runtime configuration of an application that affects how
security controls are used.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Security Control</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A function or component that performs a security check (e.g., an
authorization check) or when called results in a security effect (e.g.,
generating an audit record).</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Security information and
event management</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (SIEM) - A system for threat
detection, compliance and security incident management through the collection
and analysis of security-related data from various sources within an
organization’s IT infrastructure.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Self-Contained Token</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A token that encapsulates one or more attributes that do not rely
on server-side state or other external storage. These tokens ensure the
authenticity and integrity of their contained attributes, enabling secure,
“stateless” information exchange across systems. Self-contained tokens are
generally secured using cryptographic techniques, such as digital signatures or
message authentication codes (MACs), to ensure the authenticity, integrity, and
in some cases the confidentiality of its data. Common examples include SAML
Assertions and JWTs.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Server-side Request Forgery</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (SSRF) – An attack that abuses functionality on the server to read
or update internal resources. The attacker supplies or modifies a URL, which
the code running on the server will read or submit data to.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Session Description Protocol</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (SDP) – A message format for setting up multimedia session (used
for example in WebRTC). Defined in RFC 4566.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Session Identifier</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> or <b>Session ID</b> – A key which identifies a stateful session
stored at the back end. Will be transfered to and from the client either as or
inside a “Reference Token”.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Session Token</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A “catch-all” phrase used in this standard to refer to the token
or value used in either stateless session mechanisms (which use a
self-contained token) or stateful session mechanisms (which use a reference
token).</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Session Traversal Utilities
for NAT</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (STUN) – A protocol used to assist NAT
traversal in order to establish peer-to-peer communications. Defined in RFC
3489.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Single-factor authenticator</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A mechanism to check that a user is authenticated. It should
either be something you know (memorized secrets, passwords, passphrases, PINs),
something you are (biometrics, fingerprint, face scans), or something you have
(OTP tokens, a cryptographic device such as a smart card).</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Single Sign-on
Authentication</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (SSO) – This occurs when a user logs
into one application and is then automatically logged into other applications
without having to re-authenticate. For example, when logging into Google, the
user will be automatically logged into other Google services such as YouTube,
Google Docs, and Gmail.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Software bill of materials</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (SBOM) - A structured, comprehensive list of all components,
modules, libraries, frameworks and other resources required to build or
assemble a software application.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Software Composition
Analysis</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (SCA) – A set of technologies designed to
analyze application composition, dependencies, libraries and packages for
security vulnerabilities of specific component versions in use. This is not to
be confused with source-code analysis which is now commonly referred to as
SAST.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Software development
lifecycle</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (SDLC) – The step-by-step process by
which software is developed going from the initial requirements to deployment
and maintenance.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>SQL Injection</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (SQLi) – A code injection technique used to attack data-driven
applications, in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry
point.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Stateful Session Mechanism</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – In a stateful session mechanism, the application retains session
state at the backend which typically corresponds to a session token, generated
using a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator (CSPRNG), which
is issued to the end user.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Stateless Session Mechanism</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A stateless session mechanism will use a self-contained token
which is passed to clients, and contains session information that is not
necessarily stored within the service which then receives and validates the
token. In reality, a service will need to have access to some session
information (such as a JWT revocation list) in order to be able to enforce
required security controls.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Static application security
testing</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (SAST) – A set of technologies designed to
analyze application source code, byte code and binaries for coding and design
conditions that are indicative of security vulnerabilities. SAST solutions
analyze an application from the “inside out” in a nonrunning state.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Threat Modeling</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – A technique consisting of developing increasingly refined
security architectures to identify threat agents, security zones, security
controls, and important technical and business assets.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Time-of-check to time-of-use</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (TOCTOU) – A situation where an application checks the state of a
resource before using that resource, but the resource’s state can be changed
between the check and the use. This can invalidate the results of the check and
cause a situation where the application performs invalid actions due to this
state mismatch.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Time based One-time
Passwords</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (TOTPs) - A method of generating an OTP
where the current time acts as part of the algorithm to generate the password.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>TLS client authentication</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU>, also called <b>Mutual TLS</b> (mTLS) – In a standard TLS
connection, a client can use the certificate provided by the server to validate
the server’s identity. Where TLS client authentication is used, the client also
uses its own private key and certificate to allow the server to also validate
the client’s identity.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Transport Layer Security</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (TLS) – Cryptographic protocols that provide communication security
over a network connection.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Traversal Using Relays
around NAT</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (TURN) – An extension of the STUN
protocol using a TURN server as a relay when direct peer-to-peer connections
cannot be established. Defined in RFC 8656.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Trusted execution
environment</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (TEE) - An isolated processing
environment in which applications can be securely executed irrespective of the
rest of the system.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Trusted Platform Module</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (TPM) – A type of HSM that is usually attached to a larger hardware
component such as a motherboard and acts as the “root of trust” for that
system.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Trusted Service Layer</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – Any trusted control enforcement point, such as a microservice,
serverless API, server-side, a trusted API on a client device that has secure
boot, partner or external APIs, and so on. Trusted means that there is no
concern that an untrusted user will be able to bypass or skip the layer or
controls implemented at that layer.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Uniform Resource Identifier</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (URI)- A unique string of characters that identifies a resource,
such as webpage, mail address, places.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Uniform Resource Locator</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (URL) – A string that specifies the location of resource on the
Internet.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Universally Unique
Identifier</span></b><span lang=EN-AU> (UUID) – A unique reference number used
as an identifier in software.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Verifier</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – The person or team that is reviewing an application against the
OWASP ASVS requirements.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>Web Real-Time Communication</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (WebRTC) – A protocol stack and associated web API used for the
transport of multimedia streams in web applications, usually in the context of
teleconferencing. Based on SRTP, SRTCP, DTLS, SDP and STUN/TURN.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>WebSocket over TLS</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (WSS) – A practice of securing WebSocket communication by layering
WebSocket over TLS protocol.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>What You See Is What You Get</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (WYSIWYG) – A type of rich content editor that shows how the
content will actually look when rendered rather than showing the coding used to
govern the rendering.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>X.509 Certificate</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> – An X.509 certificate is a digital certificate that uses the
widely accepted international X.509 public key infrastructure (PKI) standard to
verify that a public key belongs to the user, computer or service identity
contained within the certificate.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo77'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'><![if !supportLists]><span lang=EN-AU
style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><b><span lang=EN-AU>XML eXternal Entity</span></b><span
lang=EN-AU> (XXE) – A type of XML entity that can access local or remote
content via a declared system identifier. This may lead to various injection
attacks.</span></span></p>

<span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-a-glossary'></span>

<h1><a name=appendix-c-cryptography-standards></a><a name="_Toc202716529"><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span lang=EN-AU>Appendix
C: Cryptography Standards</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
lang=EN-AU>The “Cryptography” chapter goes beyond simply defining best
practices. It aims to enhance understanding of cryptography principles and
encourage the adoption of more resilient, modern security methods. This
appendix provides detailed technical information regarding each requirement,
complementing the overarching standards outlined in the “Cryptography” chapter.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
lang=EN-AU>This appendix defines the level of approval for different
cryptographic mechanisms:</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo83'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Approved (A) mechanisms can be
used in applications.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo83'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Legacy mechanisms (L) should
not be used in applications but might still be used for compatibility with
existing legacy applications or code onyly. While the usage of such these
mechanisms is currently not considered to be a vulnerability in itself, they
should be replaced by more secure and future-proof mechanisms as soon as
possible.</span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo83'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;

style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:aes-cipher-modes'><span
lang=EN-AU>Block ciphers, such as AES, can be used with different modes of
operations. Many modes of operations, such as Electronic codebook (ECB), are

cipher block chaining message authentication code (CCM) modes of operations
provide authenticated encryption and should be used in modern applications.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:aes-cipher-modes'><span
lang=EN-AU>Notes:</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo87'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span style='mso-bookmark:
cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:aes-cipher-modes'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>All encrypted messages must be
authenticated. For ANY use of CBC mode there MUST be an associated hashing MAC
algorithm to validate the message. In general, this MUST be applied in the
Encrypt-Then-Hash method (but TLS 1.2 uses Hash-Then-Encrypt instead). If this
cannot be guaranteed, then CBC MUST NOT be used. The only application where
encryption without a MAC algorithm is allowed is disk encryption.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo87'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span style='mso-bookmark:
cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:aes-cipher-modes'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>If CBC is used, it shall be
guaranteed that the verification of the padding is performed in constant time.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo87'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span style='mso-bookmark:
cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:aes-cipher-modes'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>When using CCM-8, the MAC tag
only has 64 bits of security. This does not conform to requirement 6.2.9 which
requires at least 128 bits of security.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-24.0pt;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo87'><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span style='mso-bookmark:
cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:aes-cipher-modes'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-AU style='mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-latin'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>•<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-AU>Disk encryption is considered
out of scope for the ASVS. Therefore this appendix does not list any approved
method for disk encryption. For this usage, encryption without authentication
is usually accepted and the XTS, XEX and LRW modes are typically used.</span></span></span></span></p>

<span style='mso-bookmark:aes-cipher-modes'></span>

<h3><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><a name=key-wrapping></a><a
name="_Toc202716535"><span style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'><span lang=EN-AU>Key
Wrapping</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'></span></span></span></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'><span
lang=EN-AU>Cryptographic key wrap (and corresponding key unwrap) is a method of
protecting an existing key by encapsulating (i.e., wrapping) it by employing an
additional encryption mechanism so that the original key is not obviously
exposed, e.g., during a transfer. This additional key used to protect the
original key is referred to as the wrap key.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'><span
lang=EN-AU>This operation may be performed when it is desirable to protect keys
in places deemed untrustworthy, or to send sensitive keys over untrusted
networks or within applications. However, serious consideration should be given
to understanding the nature (e.g., the identity and the purpose) of the
original key prior to committing to a wrap/unwrap procedure as this may have
repercussions for both source and target systems/applications in terms of
security and especially compliance which may include audit trails of a key’s
function (e.g., signing) as well as appropriate key storage.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'><span
lang=EN-AU>Specifically, AES-256 MUST be used for key wrapping, following </span></span></span></span><a
href="https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/sp/800/38/f/final"><span style='mso-bookmark:
appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span
style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'><span lang=EN-AU>NIST SP 800-38F</span></span></span></span><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span style='mso-bookmark:
cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'></span></span></span></a><span
style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span style='mso-bookmark:
cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:key-wrapping'><span lang=EN-AU>
and considering forward-looking provisions against the quantum threat. Cipher
modes using AES are the following, in order of preference:</span></span></span></span></p>

<h3><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><a name=authenticated-encryption></a><a
name="_Toc202716536"><span style='mso-bookmark:authenticated-encryption'><span
lang=EN-AU>Authenticated Encryption</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:
authenticated-encryption'></span></span></span></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:authenticated-encryption'><span
lang=EN-AU>With the exception of disk encryption, encrypted data must be
protected against unauthorized modification using some form of authenticated
encryption (AE) scheme, usually using an authenticated encryption with
associated data (AEAD) scheme.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:authenticated-encryption'><span
lang=EN-AU>The application should preferably use an approved AEAD scheme. It
might alternatively combine an approved cipher scheme and an approved MAC
algorithm with a Encrypt-then-MAC construct.</span></span></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:cipher-algorithms'><span style='mso-bookmark:authenticated-encryption'><span
lang=EN-AU>MAC-then-encrypt is still allowed for compatibility with legacy
applications. It is used in TLS v1.2 with old ciphers suites.</span></span></span></span></p>

<h2><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><a
name=message-authentication-codes-mac></a><a name="_Toc202716546"><span
style='mso-bookmark:message-authentication-codes-mac'><span lang=EN-AU>Message
Authentication Codes (MAC)</span></span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:message-authentication-codes-mac'></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bookmark:appendix-c-cryptography-standards'><span
style='mso-bookmark:message-authentication-codes-mac'><span lang=EN-AU>Message
Authentication Codes (MACs) are cryptographic constructs used to verify the
integrity and authenticity of a message. A MAC takes a message and a secret key
as inputs and produces a fixed-size tag (the MAC value). MACs are widely used
in secure communication protocols (e.g., TLS/SSL) to ensure that messages
exchanged between parties are authentic and intact.</span></span></span></p>

<h1><a name=appendix-d-recommendations></a><a name="_Toc202716549"><span
